retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: biosphere,geosphere we had lots of plants and stuff to grow and we had trees for animals we have a rain water collecter
feedback: fantastic answer linking the local action into something that can be used in a science lesson.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

retrieved_chunks.content:
Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our main subject was creating a carbon monitor connected to the classroom windows, so when there isn't enough air, the windows open automatically. That allows more air in the classroom, and no wasted time getting up to close the window. Also, the window frame would be made from aluminium which is sustainable. We also had chairs made out of the uniform from the year 6 leavers to stop wasting clothes that could be used for something entirely different. The uniform would also make the chairs comfy and match the colour of the school.
feedback: This learner identifies the issues associated with their design and explains the main component marks well.  However they fail to fully explain the link on the follow up answer.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer:
Earth's Natural Systems include:
Hydrosphere - all water on Earth (oceans, lakes, rivers, groundwater, rain)
Atmosphere - the air around our planet (weather, climate, air quality)
Biosphere - all living things and where they live (plants, animals, habitats)
Geosphere - the solid parts of Earth (soil, rocks, mountains)
feedback: again repeating the question with No thought of the actual processes.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: I think if all schools in Wales used my feature, the schools would end up being both environmentally friendly and a fun place for children to play. Plus my design would help schools both a) pay less in the summers for electricity and b) potentially get more money, as I know that the Government will pay you for the electricity you make and end up not using.
feedback: Fantastic answer making clear links between environment and energy use and sustainabilty

query_rewriter.only_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: We were doing the outside and we included Biosphere in our work. We want to encourage more insects to come to our school and make a better place for the pupils to be in.
feedback: A lovely response that again takes a simple idea but developes that idea through use of connectives and explanation.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: our design connected to quite a few of the earth's systems such as: the hydrosphere by including a water purifier that would make rainwater our drinking water. the biosphere by giving animals little habitats such as ponds, bug hotels, the green roofs and bushes the geosphere by using our food waste as compost to help our soil
feedback: Fantastic response linking to different systems of the world such as hysosphere but also making the links to a local design level.  Student also mentioned more than one system and then started to explain links.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our main project was the carbon monitor. The carbon monitor monitored the carbon levels in the room and when it went to high the windows automatically opened which then the classroom was filled with fresh air. This design had many design features as we focused on how we can make the air quality better in the classroom which comes under The Earth's Atmosphere. Our design feature also included building materials for the monitor itself and the windows. Also its biodiversity features which we used as a biophilic design for the windows and a biodegradable plastic for the carbon monitor. In the project we thought a lot about how we can make our design more Eco- friendly which took a lot of consideration and thinking when thinking for designs. Our design will have such a positive impact on the planet. We focused on how we can help the planet and not how we can make it better. This is because we need to help the planet in steps and do little things which have a great outcome. Like how we can make the air quality in the classroom better which allows major health benefits for young people as with fresh air it increases focus,happy moods and a more positive way to look at learning.
feedback: This is an emplorary answer.  The learner looks at a range of environmental issues and clearly responds and identifies different systems.  Linking the positivity of varoius systems to health benefits.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

feedback: Make links to the evironment but fails to identify fully how this is linked to systems.  However a fabulous idea.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.

metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer:
the systems are biosphere and Geosphere 
these systems work well together because all living things in the biosphere there habitats are soil rocks mountains ect which is the Geosphere. a positive change my features make for the environment are helping the enviroment by rebuilding the habitats
feedback: This learners response is a hard one to mark.  Their initial anser and link to biospohere etc.  is excellent and well understood.  Unfortunately they fail to discuss what their actual feature and design is.

query_rewriter.only_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

retrieved_chunks.content: Question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

metadata.original_question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
metadata.original_answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
metadata.feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: If all schools in Wales installed carbon monitors which automatically open windows, kids would be breathing fresher air and it could also prevent kids getting sick more often. This would also reduce the need for energy-intensive ventilation systems.
feedback: Shows the linking of carbon to climate change and how reducing benefits local as in people and global as in climate change.

metadata.original_answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
metadata.feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

metadata.original_question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
metadata.original_answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
metadata.feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.
